div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,590] ALEXANDRIA, FRIDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.
COmmencing October 1st the through Teasmers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said every Monday at 5 p.m.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined Fare to London by sea and train de uxe via Brindisi or via Marseilles £22.9.11
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Sues for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Adem. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinsi) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: Calvert's Carbolic Toilet Soap
div.p: Ensures a Clear, Soft Skin.

It is pure throughout, fragrantly perfumed, emollient, and antisceptic, (10% crystal carbolic). It quickly removes dust and dirt, takes away the unpleasant effects of perspiration, and leaves instead a delicious feeling of thorough purification.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head: Sudan Government. NOTICE
div.p: Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to enter into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers in presence of an official or other reliable witness. 28283A-30-10-9C6

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.
After a dull and showery morning the weather became more settled yesterday afternoon, and this morning the sky is cloudless. The wind is westerly and the barmoter steady.

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1906

div.head: A MORAL FOR ENGLAND
div.p: A MORAL FOR ENGLAND

Mr. J.L. Garvin contributes to the "Outlook" a thoughtful study apropos of the centenary of Jena. "Modern research and reflection," he writes, "have dispelled the ordinary legend of Jena, and the true moral of that battle is probably more useful to the English people at this moment than to Germans themselves. It was not caused only—it was not caused mainly

the Frederician military system or by absolute inefficiency of the Prussian army. No. Chastise] ment was visited upon the accumulated faults of an optimistic nation and a procrastinating Government. The campaign was lost before it began, and Prussia was enslaved, dismembered, and temporarily destroyed as a GreatbPower chiefly as the result of neglect and stagnation in domestic policy—especially respecting military and social reform—and by a policy of indecision, hardly distinguishable from perfidy, in foreign affairs. Unlike the ruthless realist who had expired twenty years before, Frederick William the Third was through and through a self-deceiver. . . . Willing to seize the territory of any neighbour wherever it could safely be done, he was a genuine, though a weak, philanthropist in the abstract, passionately devoted to the ideal of peace, desirous of getting more territory without fighting for it, and covering a policy of considerable dishonour by the self-excusing casuistry of a pietistic sentimentalism. . , . Austerlitz was fought. Austiian and Russian were crushed. The retreating Tsar Alexander concluded no formal peace, but left sixty thousand Russian troops encamped in Germany and at the disposal of Prussia. . . . England had offered Frederick William large subsidies if he should be driven to extremity. He was placed in the strongest possible position for negotiation by the diplomacy of London and St. Petersburg, and he resolved to negotiate exclusively in his own interests. Napoleon played for' time with consummate policy. He knew the interior nature of the Prussian conscience and offered— Hanover. That electorate belonged to an intimately friendly sovereign, the King of England. To occupy it would make Prussia tho ally and accomplice of tho Cassar, and would be an act of cynical duplicity unprecedented oven in the diplomacy of that time. But tho prize was splendid, and Frederick William's over-scrupulous conscionce assured him on reflection that the proceeding was legitimate. Hanover was seized ; and Buonaparte's wicked knowledge of self-deceiving human nature was triumphant. Austria had been forced to make peace by Prussia's desertion. England was driven tp declare war against Prussian aggression. The Tsar's contingent was dismissed from Prussian soil by Prussian ineptitude. Frederick William even disbanded the greater part of his own army now that he had obtained Hanover. Then—then—when he stood stripped of dignity and power, a doomed figure clutching plunder .... Napoleon offered Hanover to England. Modern history knows no such touch of Satanic irony. Frederick William committed the supreme folly. Having failed to act with Austria and Russia the year before, he now determined with his isolated and unready forces to challenge his overwhelming opponent .... The moral Jena had preceded the memorable campaign now to open." After tracing the military drama in swift outlines,' Mr. Garvin concludes:—"The blow fell upon Prussia when the need of military reconstruct tion had been widely recoghised and in the midst of hesitating inclinations towards halfand-half reforms. The army was commanded by superannuated officers who ought to have been removed because they had served under Frederick the Great. For a number of years a far-kighted minority had passionately pressed for the introduction of universal service, for the creation of a great national reserve. The king, like Mr. Haldane, was half- convincd. Yet numbers of patriotic Prussians, foreseeing the ultimate danger, had clearly understood and explained Napoleon's methods. All were unheeded. And why was effective reform postponed some chief reasons appear. Prussia enjoyed unusual prosperity. Comfort had never been so widely diffused. The air _ was full of a vague Liberalism. Optimistic sentimentalism prevailed. Budgets were framed upon the principles of economy at any price. Worst of all, the fact that in the period before Jena a genuine belief in the approach of universal peace was widely held, and proposals for European disarmament wero mooted. . . The Prussian army of 1806 was beaten by Latin genius; its successor might be beaten by Latin genius again. But behind it stands tho inexhaustible réserve of the'nation in arms . .

The overwhelming probabilities are that Germany will not be permanently confined to her present limits ; that her furthest reaching ambitions, nevertheless, will be powerfully and finally checked; but that she «ill not uguin go down in a day, nor without honour, nor without a struggle which will convulse the Continent before another disastrous sunset sinks upon the ascendency of her arms.

div.head: Pilgrims at Suez.
div.p: A special landing stage is to be built at Suez for the embarkation and disembarkation of pilgrims.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe, via Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G. P. 0., Alexandria, at 8.30 a.m. on Sunday.

div.head: Sudan Industrial Schools.
div.p: The Sudan Government intends to establish an industrial school at Omdurman and at Kassala. A third is contemplated at El Obeid, Kordofan.

div.head: The Opera Season.
div.p: The repertoire of the Italian opera company which is to give performances at the Abbas Theatre, Cairo, next season will include Amica and Macbeth.

div.head: Jardin Francais.
div.p: A gala performance will be given on Saturday for the debut of Libre et Change, which could not take place on Wednesday owing to the rain.

div.head: Weights and Measures.
div.p: Captain Moore, the active officer of the Port Said police, has seized a quantity of false weights and measures which he found in various shops. Proceedings will ensue.

div.head: H. M. S. Terrible.
div.p: The cruiser Terrible left Port Said early yesterday morning for Malta, where she will go into dry-dock for the repair of her broken propeller.

div.head: Egyptian University.
div.p: Dr. Eloui Pasha has promised a subscription of L E. 1,000 for the establishment of an Egyptian University on condition that it will observe strict religious neutrality.

div.head: Land Seal.
div.p: The Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, has purchased the Souaya estate from the Comptoir Franco-Egyptien, consisting of 45,000 square pics, at the price of P.T. 180 per pic.

div.head: Inniskilling Dragoon's Reconnaissance.
div.p: The Inniskilling Dragoons passed through Abou-Kebir yesterday morning en route to Simbellawein, accompanied by an inspector of the Ministry of the Interior.

div.head: Church of Scotland, Cairo.
div.p: The morning and evening services of St. Andrew's Church of Scotland, Cairo, have now been resumed, the hours of service being 10.30 a.m. and 6 p.m.

div.head: Collape of a Shed
div.p: A shed attached to the engineering workshops belonging to Messrs. Koster, in the Souk el Ghanem, collapsed yesterday, probably in consequence of the heavy rains. Fortunately no one was injured.

div.head: Hisratic Papyrl.
div.p: The Royal Museum of Berlin has just issued part 9 of volumeIII. of its collection of Hieratic Papyri. The manuscripts given are from Elephantine, and many are as old as the 6th dynasty, so competing in point of antiquity with those discovered by Dr. Petrie at Gurob.

div.head: Native Appeal Court,
div.p: Ali Eff. Z ice El-Arabi, Mohamed Eff. Abon el Kheir, Younis Eff. Salih, advocates of Cairo; Ahmed Eff. Tewfik, Tantah; Emile Eff. Ratl, Beni Sonef, and Tewfik Eff. Doss, Assiout, have been anthorised to practise as advocates before the Native Court of Appeal.

div.head: Dynamite Explosion.
div.p: Some natives employed in blasting in the Khalifa quarter of Cairo had a narrow escape yesterday from the stones displaced by the explosion of a dynamite cartridge. One, indeed, was struck on the head, and had to be removed to hospital suffering from severe concussion and loss of blood.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 24th October, 11 vessels, of which 4 were northward and 7 southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 320,948.28. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 6,634,298.94, and during that time 243 vessels transited the Canal, 107 being northward, and 136 southward bound.

div.head: Highway Robbery.
div.p: Last week a cotton grower of Mehallet- Kobra, in Gharbieh province, was attacked by highwaymen, who, after stabbing him, robbed him of his earnings. He was afterwards able to identify his aggressors, who are now in custody. Not so long ago, a headless corpse was found in the same neighborhood_— the grim trophy of murder.

div.head: The Poet Office Forgery Case.
div.p: The ease of Ibrahim Ragi, who, in collaboration with the proprietor of "AI Umma," forged a signature in order to obtain a money order from the Cairo Post Office, will come before the Cairo Criminal Court on the 6th itst. The accused has not yet been arrested, despite the efforts of the polioe, but will nevertheless be tried and sentenced in absentia.

div.head: Egyptian Mummy Tickets.
div.p: Mr. H,R. Hall, of the British Museum, whose Corpus of Mummy Tickets in that collection was published by the Society of Biblical Archaeology last year, has just, edited for the Museum Trustees the "Series of Coptio and Greek Texts of the Christian Period" from ostraoa, stelæ and other monuments. The work is illustrated by 100 plates, and is of great interest to all parsons studying early Egyptian Christianity.

div.head: CAN EGYPT GOVERN ITSELF?
PROOF TO THE CONTRARY
div.p: One of the stock theories of the native Press is that, inasmuch as Egypt is capable of self- government, therefore it should be endowed with representative institutions. This forms the theme of countless leading articles in the columns of our vernacular contemporaries, and "Al Moayad" and "Al Lewa" are tireless in calling upon England to redeem her pledges and forthwith begin to endow this country with parliamentary government of the European type.

But instead of the natives becoming more capable of self-government we see that the reverse is the case, for as Egypt progresses the Government finds that it is more and more necessary to increase the number of European officials without a corresponding increase in the native staff.

A striking example of this is evidenced in recent appointments to the Ministry of Finance. Last year an eminent English financial authority was appointed from outside to the important post of Director of the Treasury. A few months afterwards it was found obligatory to increase the English high officials in this Ministry by appointing a second Under-Secretary of State, and now the Government intends to make use of the great experience of Chitty Bey and to transfer him from thé director-generalship of the Customs Administration to an important newly created post in the same Ministry.

All these gentlemen have been appointed to these high positions because, in the opinion of the Government, there is not a single native capable of fulfilling such duties, despite the fact that we have been trying to educate the Egyptians to govern themselves for over twenty years. Moreover, it is not only in the highest ranks that this spectacle is seen, for now every year batches of Oxonians and Cantabs are selected to fill the lower administrative posts, evidently because the younger generation of natives, in spite of their having been educated under British superintendence, are incapable of filling these positions.
No Progress Made.

As Mr. Edward Dicey wrote in 1902 : "I cannot see that we have made much progress as yet towards the avowed object of our policy, as propounded in Lord Dufferin's report, namely, that of reorganizing the administration of Egypt on enlightened ideas, so as to render the country capable of governing itself in accordance with these ideas supposing our troops should be withdrawn. What progress has been made towards this end seems to me of the crab order—backwards. Our theory of teaching Egypt how to govern herself by enabling her to enjoy the advantages of just, honest and progressive administration under British control, however sincerely the theory was conceived, and however loyally it has been carried ont, was based on a delusion. England has indeed succeeded in establishing a system of administration in Egypt, which is an enormous improvement upon any Government the country has ever known, but this systems depends for its vitality upon its being carried out by British officials. It the work was left in the hands of native officials not subject to British authority, "the old abuses of all Oriental governments would revive at once. Tutelage is an excellent system for administering the affairs of persons incompetent to manage by themselves : but this system does not tend to render the persons under tutelage competent administrators."

The longer therefore that England remains in Egypt, the less and less capable will Egyptians become of self-government and, that this is the case is seen in the greater number of appointments of Englishmen to official positions in Egypt, especially in the instance of the Finance Ministry, which we gave above, where after all these years new and highly-paid posts have to be created which no Egyptian is competent to fill. It is an inevitable consequence of the existing state of things, for as the power of the State grows the energy of the individual must dwindle. As a relent observer said : "If ever the activity of the State should extend through and through to every department of life, the universal ease and comfort which may be thus disseminated throughout society will have been purchased dearly at the price of the soul. The denizens of that State will be fed, housed, and clothed to perfection : only--and it is a serious drawback— they will be dead." This is a tendency of all modern civilized, states and especially so is it the case with modern Egypt, where the Government is all in all. It is useless for our native contemporaries therefore to talk about self-government, for, as Mr. Dicey says, any progress in that direction in Egypt has been of the crab order—backwards.

div.head: QUARANTINE
div.p: Medical visit with disinfection and deratisation is declared against arrivals at Constantinople from Adalia and Fort Said.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Fiorio-Rubattino S.S. Perseo, due at Alexandria on Sunday, left Naples six hours behind time, owing to a shore porters' strike at Naples. Weather permitting, however, she should reach here at 3 p.m. on Sunday.
The Messageries steamer Niger arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria on Wednesday morning.
The Moss liner Menes arrived this morning from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The S.S. Scottish Prince lift Malta ye-ter day for Manchester with passengers) and general cargo.

div.head: NEW CAIRO OPERA HOUSE
FOUNDATIONS BEGUN.
div.p: Preparations for the destruction of the Esbekieh Gardens, and, incidentally, the deprival of Cairo of one of its now too few lungs, for the purpose of building a new opera house, are proceeding apace. M. Santi, proprietor of the garden restaurant, has received notice to quit on the 1st of February and the digging of foundations has already commenced.

A contemporary states that the selection of the site was decided upon by Sir Vincent Corbett, but we can hardly believe that. So important a matter would surely be decided by a committee, and only after great consideration, especially in view of the fact that the director- general of the Public Health Department expressed his strong disapproval of the site now selected. Unfortunately, the public health of Egypt receives far too scant attention, as has been well evidenced in Alexandria by the disease-pregnant odours which have been caused in almost every district of the town by the recent heavy rain.

div.head: EPIDEMIC OF DENGUE
div.p: There have been a considerable number of cases of dengue at Cairo lately, and we hear that a perfect epidemic of this unpleasant complaint is raging at Keneh and Assouan. It is suggested that the recent appearance of mosquitoes—till lately almost unknown at Assouan—may explain the increase of dengue at the latter locality.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive arrived at Ras-el-Tin Palace from Montazah at 10 o'clock this morning, and attended midday prayers at Abonsinn Mosque.
His Highness will grant a private audience to Lord Cromer this afternoon.

div.head: LORD CROMER.
div.p: Lord Cromer arrived at Alexandria from Cairo at 1 p.m. to-day, and was met at the station by Mr. E. B. Gould. I.S.0, H.B.M.'s Consul-General, and Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of Police. His lordship lunched at the British Consultant afterwards proceeded to Ras-el-Tin Palace, where he was received in private audience by the Khedive. He will return to Cairo by the afternoon express.
Lord Cromer paid a visit to the Governor of Cairo on Wednesday afternoon.

div.head: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE
div.p: The rumour is current that Ismail Pasha Sabri, Under-Secretary of State to the Ministry of Justice, is about to resign, and that he will be replaced by Saleh Pasha Sabet, president of the Native Court of Appeal, to which post Judge Bond would probably succeed. Other papers categorically contradict this news.

div.head: HAIFA-AKABA RAILWAY.
div.p: "Al Ahram" is informed by a recent arrival from Damascus that the Turkish Government has prepared plans for a new branch of the Ottoman Railways, to run from Haifa to Akaba, passing through Wadi-el-Arab.

div.head: REFORM IN EGYPT
div.p: It is said that next week will see important revelations concerning the reformswith which Lord Cromer and the Advisers have been so busily occupied since his lordship's return.

div.head: THE ARABIC DRAMA
div.p: In an interesting article contributed to the "Moayad," a critic discusses the suggestion made by several Arabic littérateurs that it is time for the Arab theatre to give Arabic dramas instead of translations of the chef-d'œuvres of European playwrights.

The writer, in reply, points oat theft while the theatre of Sheikh Salama El HegazI is well managed and supplied with excellent scenery and accessories, the Arab companies have not yet the prestige of European players, nor are they yet capable of interpreting the more subtle character studies of the greatest dramatists. As kings, conspirators, faithful friends, and passionate lovers, they succeed and will in time, no doubt, essay more complex rôles with success. Meantime the Arab theatre is still young. Its development man come sooner or later, but there is no reason to hurry on the composition of native dramas till both the literary and the dramatic capacity, necessary to do justice to them, have reached a higher stage of development,

div.head: TRAM CAR COLLISION
div.p: As a tram-car was running along Ramleh-boulevard yesterday afternoon it collided with considerable force with a cab which was drawing op at the door of Messrs. Barker and Co.'s office. The cab was split into two pieces, the box being entirely separated from the body. Mr. Cyril Barker, who was seated in the cab, had a very narrow escape of being seriously injured, but be jumped ont of the cab just in time to save himself. Curiously enough, Mr. Barker's father was knocked down by a carriage is Cherif Pasha this morning, but fortunately received no serious injuries

div.head: SHOPPING IN EGYPT British and Foreign Methods
div.p: In England during the last decade the gentle art of shopping has undergone somewhat of a revolution. A run up to town for a few days for that purpose is no longer essential. Postal facilities and elaborately illustrated catalogues enable the purchaser in the majority of instances do all that is necessary from his or her armchair.

English trades-people are alive to the importance of this branch of their business, and a small order through the post receives the same careful attention as a larger one over the counter. They are aware that a customer who is satisfied is an advertisement for them, personal experience acquired in the Sudan, to and fuss result is a largely extended trade.

Here in Egypt it is not always conveinent for people living in the provinces to visit Cairo or Alexandria in order to do their shopping, and the era of illustrated catalogues has not yet dawned, so they have to rely on the care and discretion of the firm with which they place their order for their satisfactory selection and dispatch.

There is little doubt that the average Englishman, be he Imperialist or Little Englander, has a natural inclination to place his orders with fellow-countrymen, but when there are foreign competitors in the same branch of trade the English houses should remember they can ill afford to concede anything in the way of courtesy or attention without seriously endangering their interests. The little homily I would venture to read them had its genesis in an incident which was recently brought to my notice.

A lady residing in the provinces wrote to three Cairo firms, one French and two English, for patterns and prices of a material which she was aware they kept in stock. By return of post she received a courteous letter in excellent English from the French firm, enclosing the patterns required. Two days later one of the English firms sent their patterns in an envelope without any covering note in reply to the question asked. The third firm never even vouchsafed an answer. The material submitted by the French house was superior in quality and cheaper than that of its English competitor,
Question of Credit.

Some time ago the writer had occasion to order a suit of clothes from an English firm in Cairo. It was the first order of that nature he had given them. He requested that the suit, when finished, should be forwarded to a provincial town, giving at the same time his Cairo address. The suit was duly forwarded contre remboursement, and he refused to accept delivery of the parcel. On writing the firm complaining that it was unreasonable to expect prior payment for a garment of which he had not even an opportunity of seeing in its finished state, he received a polite letter of apology informing him that the parcel had beau re-despatched in the ordinary way. In this letter, the firm stated they had frequently been victimized, not invariably by their fellow- countrymen, and had therefore been obliged to adopt this precautionary measure. The writer had been introduced to the firm by a customer of theirs to whom they allowed a liberal credit. It is not unreasonable to assume the existence in Egypt of a bureau of information analogons to the Trades Protection Society in England, and in any case, it would not bave been difficult for the firm to have ascertained whether the writer was in the habit of meeting his liabilities.

Incidents such as the foregoing tend to explain how it is possible for a London firm of tailors to send a representative to Egypt each winter to book orders at a moderate price for which a year's credit is allowed.

Again, some English houses in Egypt exhibit a reprehensible laxity in dealing with their correspondence. A remittance which the writer sent to a firm a week ago in settlement of their account has not, up to date, been acknowledged, although he has received an invoice for goods ordered at the same time.

The writer knows of several instances where English people have diverted their orders to a French firm. The reason given is that they receive better attention, the goods are more carefully dispatched, fewer mistakes being made in executing the orders and in the rendering of accounts, and greater pains are taken in procuring from an outside source without extra charge, such goods as the firm does not happen to have in stock for the time being.

In more than one establishment in Cairo it is extremely difficult for English people to make their wants understood by the assistants, who, while-professing some knowledge of the language, are insufficiently versed therein to enable them to intelligently interpret a customer's demands. An Englishman's attempts at French or Italian are, not infrequently, correspondingly obscure, causing a rupture of negotiations pending the arrival on the scene of a gentleman qui parle l'Anglais parfaitement.

Should the foregoing remarks meet the eye of any of those responsible for the conduct of English establishments each as I have, in a general way, ventured to criticize, it is not impossible some improvement may ensue in the direction indicated, bringing a meed of satisfaction to the customer, and, let as hope, a larger measure of prosperity to the houses concerned.
In such event the object of the writer will have been attained.

div.head: DRINK IN THE SUDAN. FACTS AND FIGURES.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette.''

Sir, —In your issue of the 22nd current, I noticed with some surprise an article entitled "Drink in the Sudan," in which it is stated that spirits to the extent of 561 tons and valued at £119,788, entered the Sudan in the year 1904 and that the value of liquor imports last year was £84,000. The article has also a head-line calling attention to an "Enormous Increase." It seems to me that far from being an enormous increase, these figures show a decrease in 1905 on the amount quoted as value in 1904.

I beg to remark that I am qualified, from personal experience acquired in the Sudan, to give somee information that will alter materially the conclusions that have been or may be drawn from a perusal of the article alluded to, and as this subject will probably occupy the attention of both House of Parliament at sometime during the present Session, I trust yon wilt extend the courtesy of your columns the what I have to say in the matter.

list.item: To the best of my knowledge, only some 20 licenses for the supply of spirituous liquors have as yet been issued by the Sudan Government. Those who hold these licenses will forfeit this privilege should they supply drink to the native Sudanese, the license being expressly for supplies to Europeans only.

An attempt was made lately to introduce inferior spirits in the Sudan. The design was doomed to failure from the outset, as only the superior brands of spirituous drinks can find purchasers. Distillers know well that only the first-class marks go to the Sudan.

The number of Europeans (who ate the sole consumers of spirituous drinks) resident in the Sudan, are, as quoted in the article, 2,787, but it must be remembered that all the beer, wine, and spirits destined for consumption in Uganda and the Lado Enclave find their way thither through the Sudan, and consequently form a part of the imports alluded to in the article
Those traders who are and have been establishing stores in the Sudan must necessarily provide stocks of spirituous drinks for licensed use. These stocks are far from being already consumed.

The weight of the liquors imported in 1904 is stated as 561 tons, which is probably accurate, but their value, which is said to be £119,738, has been glaringly exaggerated. To get a correct estimate of value, it is only necessary to recall a well-known fact, viz., that liquors go into the Sudan in cases. Forty cases of wine or spirits go to a ton, and each ease contains 12 bottles. There are 10 cases of beer to a ton, and each case contain 48 bottles. My extended experience tells me that the 561 tons would represent as follows:

div.p: 224 tons of beer of the import
168 tons of whisky of the import
142 tons of assorted spirits, wines,
27 tons of champagne.... £2,430
This amount of £17,648 is practically the value of the 561 tons of spirituous liquors imported in 1904, and not £119,738.

Again, 561 tons of miscellaneous drinking liquors world average about 15,720 cases. These on the assumption that their value was £119,738 would give an average all-round value of £7.12 per case, which is absurd.
I beg to enclose my card, which yon will recognize as bearing a well known name in the Sudan, and remain, Yours very truly,
A Sudan Merchant.
Alexandria, 95th October.

[The figures for 1904, L.E. 119,738, which our correspondent declares to have been 'glaringly exaggerated," are in accordance with Lord Cromer's Report (Egypt, No. 1, 1905, pages 121-122). Lord Cromer appends the following note: "The valuation of L.E 119,738 would appear to be unusually high. 1 am, however, informed that "this bulk of the spirituous liquors which come into the Sudan is of good quality." In the same Report Lord Cromer says that "the attention of Sir Reginald Wingate has been drawn to the subject. The sale of liquors in the Sudan shall be carefully watched, and if necessary, controlled,"—Ed. EG.]

div.head: EDUCATION IN EGYPT. To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"
div.p: Dear Sir, —In your article of yesterday and to-day on "Egyptian Education" your correspondent seems to be under some missapprehension with regards to the Secondary Schools.

The years in the Secondary Schools have not been reduced from three to two. On the contrary, they have been extended from three to four, and no student can take his Secondary Certificate until he has studied four years in a Secondary School.

The cause of the misapprehension seems to have been the introduction of a "half-way house" examination into the middle of the four years Secondary Course. The examination qualifies for the "Subordinate Service Certificate" which in no way supersedes the Secondary Certificate, but is intended, after a short period, to qualify for posts which may now be obtained by holders of a Primary Certificate. —Yours truly, R.P.K.
Shibin el Kem, October 24.

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: Two admissions of bubonic cases of plague to Alexandria hospital are reported, the first being a Greek boy from an oil shop in the Minet el Bassal quarter, and the second a native boy from the Custom House quarter. Both cases have been isolated since Wednesday

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Sirdar, Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, came down to Alexandria from Cairo this morning, and was received in private audience by the Khedive at Ras-el Tin Palace at 10 a.m.
Prince Cantaouzsne is staying at Shepherd's Hotel
Baron Edmund de Gaiffler d'Hestroy is to succeed M. Léon Maskens as Belgian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General.
The German and Greek Vice Consul-General were received by the Prime Minister in audience yesterday morning
Rear-Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blomfield are due at Port Said, on their return from Europe, on the 30th inst.
Ali Bey Cherif has returned to Cairo.
Dr. J.G. Macdonald has been appointed sub-inspector of the ophthalmic hospital.
Major H.B. Protheree Smith in command of the Military Mounted Police is expected at Alexandria to-morrow
Capt. E. K. Parnell, 1st Batt. Lancashire Fusiliers, has joined the troops engaged on a reconnaissance march through the Delta.
Lient F. H. C., Frankland, 1st Batt Royal Dublin Fusiliers, will leave for Cyprus tomorrow for the annual inspection of the signallers.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. Alexandria Swimming Club.
div.p: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
At the last meeting of the Alexandria Swimming Club the following championships were decided:
100 yards juniors, for silver cup presented by the captains of merchant steamers visiting this port:
C.E.L Randald 1st, J.H. Mitchinson 2nd, and T. Bent 3rd. Won with consummate ease, 6 yards separating 2nd and 3rd

220 yard seniors, for silver cup presented by H.H. Prince Aziz Hassan Pasha.- E.A Darton 1st, F.E. Howard 2nd, and A.A. Ecclestone 3rd. Won by 2 yards, 3 feet separating 2nd and 3rd. Time 3.2 4/5 see. A well-contested race, the three finalists swimming together for about 100 yards, when Howard gradually forged ahead, followed closely by Darton and Ecclestone. Howard led slightly at 210 yards, when Darton put on a sprint and won.

To-morrow the 440 yards championship will take place, for which a handsome silver challenge shield has been presented by Montagu Summers Eq, which will be followed by the usual polo match. Boats will leave the marina at 3 o'clock.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est toujours à 5 7/8 pour cent. Hier, au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié à 85 7/8, de même que l'Uflifiée à 104. La National Bank, l'Agricole et les autres valeurs égyptiennes ont également conservé leurs prix de la veille.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a réactionné de 2 francs à 782. La Banque d'Athènes est revenue à 144.

L'amélioration qui s'était dessinée hier sur notre marché des valeurs s'est vivement accentuée ce matin. Les transactions ont été nombreuses et une plus-value sensible s'est manifestée, au début, sur presque toute la ligne de la cote. A noter qu'un petit tassement, amené par des réalisations, s'est produit, vers le milieu de la séance, sur les titres qui avaient le plus bénéficié du mouvement.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a débuté à 27 3/8 pour finir à 27 3/16- 1/4. L'Agricole a progressé à 9 3/16, acheteurs, pour mollir a 9 3/4-13/16. La Cassa di Seonto a avancé à 243-244 l'action ancienne et 238 la nouvelle. Le Comptoir Financier s'est tenu à 6 15/16-7 l'action ancienne ; l'action nouvelle a gagné 1/16 à 6 3/4.

Le Crédit Foncier est revenu à 782-783. La Daïra s'est raffermie à 16 15/16-17. La Béhéra a encore gagné 1/4 de livre a 40 1/4. La Nile Land a été traitée à 16 3/16-1/4. La part de fondateur Immobilière a passé de 740 à 760. L'Union Foncière a haussé à 6 7/16-1/2.
Les Improvements ont été fort recherchés et ont clôturé à 6 1/4-5/16; on verra, certes, des prix plus élevés, pleinement motivés d'ailleurs.
Continuant son mouvement ascensionnel, l'Allotment a dépassé un moment le pair pour réactionner fortement à 3 13/16; la part de fondateur a atteint 177 pour revenir à 170.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont avancé à 273. La Frigorifique s'est raffermie à 4 7/8- 15/16. Les Automobiles sont remontées à 6 1/2.

L'action Express Nile a avancé à 3 5,8- 11/16. On a remarqué des achats faits discrètement par des personnes au courant, qui semblent s'être employées à ramasser le peu de flottant existant surplace; on peut d's lors présager des prix beaucoup plus hauts dans un bref délai.

Le groupe des valeurs hôtelières a été spécialement actif. Les Nungovich ont passé à 18 7/16-1/2, les Egyptian à 7 1/2 et les Upper Egypt à 5 B/8-'l 1/16. Les National se sont consolidés à 4 1/8 ; leur part de fondateur a progressé à 80.

Il y a un mouvement significatif sur les Excelsior qui, de 3 7/8, ont clôturé à 4 1/16, acheteurs. Cette hausse est, évidemment, le résultat forcé de la plus-value considérable acquise par le terrain de la Société. Il s'agit de 5,500 mètres. carrés environ, dont le prix de revient par mètre est L.E. 22 et qui est évalué aujourd'hui L.E. 38. Ce surcroît d'actif de L.E. 88,000 a son importance, ne fùt-ce qu'au point de vue d'un simple calcul, le nombre total des actions n'étant que de 37,500.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land a atteint 3 15/16 pour clôturer à 3 7/8-15/16. Les Estates ont progressé- aux abords de 2 1/4 pour terminer à 2 1/8-3/16. Les Hooker sont restés a 1 1/8-3/16 ; on rapporte que le Trust vient d'acheter, en participation avec un groupe, un excellent terrain de construction, de 50,000 pics carrés sis à Alexandrie, rue Menasce, pour la somme de L.E. 90,000, soit à P.E. 180 le pic. Les Walker and Meimarachi ont faibli à 0 5/8-11/16 et les Abdy à 1 1/4-5/16.
Nous détachons d'une lettre de Londrea, en date du 19 Octobre, le passage suivant:

"La Banque d'Angleterre a pris aujourd'hui, vendredi, la décision extraordinaire d'eéever son taux d'escompte de 5 à 6 % et notre marché a éprouvé le contre-coup de cette surprise. La mesure a été motivée par de grosses demandes d'or pour l'étranger, pour l'Egypte notamment.

"Quand on considére la situation actuelle de la Banque et la violence du courant qui emporte son or au dehous, on s'explique la necessité de cette decision. Depuis le 11 Octobre elle a du se laisser enlever plus de £3,000,000 sur lesquelles l"Egypte a pris la plus grosse part. Il y a lieu de croire que ce pays sera bientot satisfait; mais il se pourrait qu'il y ait des demandes de l'Amerique de Sud, qui, jusqu'à maintenant, contro toute attente, s'est abstenue de prendre part au pillage du stock métallique de la Banque.

"A New-York, la situation tend à s'ameliorer. D'aprés le dernier bilan des Banques associées, la réserve s'est accrue de 8 1/2 millions de dollars et dépasse de 13 millions le minimum se-dessous duquel la loi lui défend de descendre.

"Faut-il s'attendre à un proche changement dans la situation monétaire générale? Il est encore difficile de se prononcer avec certitude. Toujours est-il que si les transactions restent languissantes au Stock Exchange, les cours n'en présentent pas moins une certaine resistance, ce qui est de bon augure."

On annonce d'Alexandrie que l'échange des titres de l'Egyptian Trust and Investment (Glymenopoulo) contre les actions Building Lands of Egypt Co. s'effectuera dans les pre-premiers jours du mois prochain,.
On sait que l'échange aura lieu à raison de 10 actions du Trust contre 3 actions Building Lands.
Or, hier, en Bourse d'Alexandrie, celles-ci ont été ramenées à £ 4 3/4-13/16 ; les actions du Trust ont clôturé a £ 1 3/8.
Les recettes des Egyptian Markets Ltd. pour la semaine au 11 Octobre se sont chiffrées par L.E. 471 contre 408 en 1905, soit en augmentation de L.E. 63.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Janvier 1906 s'élèvent à LE. 26,731 contre 20,074 en 1905, soit en plus-value de LE. 6,657 pour l'exercice courant.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Auiourd'hui à midi et demie.)

Il y a eu oe matin nn peu de nervosité avec des périodes alternatives de faiblesse et de fermeté. Malgré une certaine tendance à réali ser, les prix sont néanmoics soutenus. Les transactions ont été limi'ées aux Cassa di Sconto, Delta Land, Estates et Comptoir.

La Ramleh hausse de 7 3/16 à 7 1/4. le Privilég'ées Tramways d'Alexandrie de 187 à 188, la Dura de 16 7/8 à 16 15/16, la Béhéra de 39 1/2 à 40 1/2, la Cassa di Sconto ancienne de 240 à 240 1/4, la Delta Land de 3 15/16 à 3 3'/32. le Trust de 1 3/8 à 1 13/32, les Splendid Hotels de 3-15/16 à 4, l'Urbaine de 6 3/8 à 6 7/16, la Building Lands de 4 13/16 à 4 7/8, et la Banque d'Orient de 134 1/2 à 135.

Par contre, l'Alexandria Water fléohit de 13 13/16 à 13 3/4, les Dividendes Bière d'Alexandrie de 125 à 124, la Salt and Soda de 23 à 22/9, la Cassa di Sconto noavelle émission de 235 à 234 1/2, la Banque d'Athènes de 145 à 144 1/2, les Nungovich de 18 7/16 à 18 3/8, la Nile Land de 16 3/16 k 16 1/8, les Sucreries de 25 1/2 k 25, la Land Bank de 9 à 8 31/32, le Comptoir de 7 1/32 et 6 3/4 à 6 15/16 et 6 11/ 6 l'aotion et de 49 1/2 à 48 3/4 la part de fondateur, l'Union Fonoière de 6 7/16 à 6 3/8 et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 6 19/32 à 5 17/32.
Les autres valeurs demeurent sans changement.
On continue à reporter les positions de fin octobre à fin novembre.

div.head: CHANNEL TUNNEL SCHEME. Submission of Plans to Governments.

div.p: The directors of the Channel Tunnel Company have resolved immediately to deposit the plans of the tunnel in England and France for the necessary preliminary promotion, next session, of a private bill authorising the scheme. (Reuter)

House or Commons —Mr. Winston Church- ill, replying to Mr. Ashley, stated that the Newfoundland Government had been consulted with regard to the fisheries agreement before the negotiations began, and were also informed of the progress of each stage. The Imperial Government were, however, not so fortunate as to obtain the Newfoundland Government's concurrence. (Reuter)

div.head: AUSTRIAN MINISTERIAL CHANGES. Statement by the Premier.

div.p: Chev. von Pitreicb, Minister of War, has resigned. M. Schoemaiob, Austrian Minister of National Defence, succeeds him.

The Austrian Premier stated isthe Reicbs- rath that Count Goluchowski. resigned spontaneously. The Hungarian Government, he said, would in future always exercise its legitimate influence in the international policy. This change would not affect the foreign policy, of which the Triple Alliance will remain the principal foundation. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIA AND JAPAN. New Commercial Treaty.

div.p: The Japanese draft of the new commercial treaty with Russia is being considered by the Foreign Office. (Reuter)

A Russian squadron, including the Slava, Tsarevitch, and Bogatyr, under Admiral Bos from, will arrive to-morrow at Barrow-in- Furness, The officers will visit the Vickers Maxim works, and London, and other places in parties. (Reuter)
Prince Alexander Hohenlohe is temporarily impended. (Havas)
The Premier has introduced a drastic anti- gambling bill (Reuter)
The Queen's nineteenth birthday was celebrated amidst general manifestations of the loyalty and affection of all classes. {Reuter)
The Chamber and the Senate will not meet November 5. (Havas)
All the tramway employés are on strike. (H.)

div.head: SINAI EXPLORATION. Prof. Flinders Petrie's Work
div.p: Professor Petrie tells in the preface to his most recent work how the short stay in the Peninsula in the winter of 1804 5, of which Researches in Sinai" is his own unofficial record, was the fulfilment of a wish cherished for twenty-six years, and the book bears eloquent testimony to the remark that the "surprises" were more important than the duty which prompted the mission. The sculptures and inscriptions of the Wady Magbareh and the valuable archæological remains of the Wady Feiran, Mount Serbal, and the Temple and Mines of Serabit have been visited by other travellers, but none has had Professor Petrie's advantages of observation or his eminent qualifications for utilising them. The result is the correction of much that was positively held by Egyptologists, and the confirmation of not a little that was previously doubted.

'The earliest signs in Egypt," writes the author, "of intercourse with Sinai are the beads of turquoise, rarely found in the prehistoric graves. . . The beginning of the monuments of Sinai is in the First Dynasty, about B.c. 5300. The seventh King of that Dynasty is here (Wady Maghareh) written as Semerkhet. . .. On a smooth natural face of the upper sandstone rock, at 394ft. above the valley floor, the scene of this king has begun engraved by sinking the ground and leaving the figures in relief. . .. The next monument. carved was that of King Sa-nekht, the founder of the Third Dynasty, about b.c. 4950."

Around Maghareh and Serabit Professor Petrie discovered adsorptions relating to thirty- nine Egyptian monarchs, down to those of Setnekht (b.c. 1203-1202) of the Nineteenth Dynasty, a hundred years subsequent to the Exodus, all of whom appear to have worshipped Harbor, or the 1 Mistress of the Turquoise"; or. in other words, to have sent mining expeditions to Sinai. The building of the Temple of Serabit, which the Professor discovered to have ultimately attained 23Gfc. in length, seems to have kept pace with the greed or reverence of these Egyptian kings. Thanks, however, to an English miring company operating in the ancient turquoise mines vast quantities of priceless sculptures and inscriptions have been ignorantly destroyed, and the author is Datn- rally bitter on this vandalism. "Everything," he writes, "gave way to the greed for dividends, with the result that the promoters lost their money, the natives lost their turquoises, and the world lost many of its most ancient monuments."

But the most remarkable portions of this volume lie in the author's deductions from his discoveries. There is font fact, or perhaps we should call them theories, which head venire with much confidence. These are : (1) That "common Syrian workmen, who could not command the skill of an Egyptian sculptor, were familiar with writing at B c. 1500, or 6C0 years before the earliest Phoenician writing known j" (2) that "we have here before ns (Temple of Serabit) a Semitic cave shrine, older than th9 Mosaic worship or any ether worship known tons in Syria or Arabia... And We see how Mo9aism was a carrying on of older ritual, how that movement was a monotheistic reformation of existing rites, and how the paganism of the Jews was bat the popular retention of more than was granted in the State religion (3) that the numbers of the Israelites of the Exodus, as given in the Book of Numbers, are shorn of their apparent exaggerations if we read the thousands (alaf) as tents or families, and the hundreds as the number of inhabitants of the tents, and that thus, instead of hundreds of thousands. we obtain the figure of five or six thousand marshalled by Moses in the Wady Feiran to do battle with the Amalekites—the anther showing that this reading is alone oncomes- rate with the life-support capacity of the Sinai Peninsula in those days as in these; and (4) that the chronology of the Egyptian dynasties which he follows in the volume mast be approximately correct—in fact, in Chapter XII. the Revision of Chronology, Professor Petrie speaks not only to the ordinary reader, hut to Egyptologists with a note of complaint that the ground arguments for Egyptian chronology have been so little re-
IIUOU.

"Researches in Sinai" is remarkably exempt from the dry-as-dust style popularly supposed to clog the pens of- desert explorers. The volume is superbly illustrated by nearly two hundred photographs and four maps. The last four chapters, in one of which the writer definitely decides on Gebel Serbal as the Mount of the Law, and suggests that the manna of the wilderness was snow, are contributed by Mr. C. T. Currelly who spent two months with Professor Petrie's party, and owing to the obduracy of Turkish soldiers at Akabah had to abandon a journey to Petra, and return to Suer by the Nakhl pilgrim route. Professor Petrie's estimate of the population of the Peninsula probably errs on the side of caution, and possibly does not include the entire country between the Suet Canal and the Wady el Araba. The following passage, however, will explain his inclination towards discrediting the number of twenty or twenty-fire thousand given by other travellers: "My wife asked him, when at our camp, if there was a village up the valley. He replied, 'Yes.' 'And how many people are there 1' 'One,' said he. This is on a par with a young Bedawy who, from the heights of Serabit, pointed ont four black tints in the far-off
valley, and exclaimed with dignity: 'Behind
the city (Medineh) of the Aleygat'—his own tribe. which is population in Sinai,"

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: The 1st Battalion King's Own Scottish Borderers, Lieutenant Colonel D. A. Mactar- lane, D.S.O., commanding, will embark at Southampton on the 21st prox. for Alexandria, per the S.S. Dongola. The battalion is due to arrive at Alexandria on the 1st December

The Government having decided to out_ down the Army without obtaining the approval of Parliament, intends, it is stated, to deal in a more drastic way with the Navy. Briefly stated, their scheme is this: Eight first-class battleships and four armoured risers are to be paid off, and eight more first-class battleships are to be removed from the sea-going list before the end of the year. In other words, the naval force which Great Britain will have ready to go to war at the shortest notice will be reduced by twenty capital ships, or about one forth. Font battleships of the Mrjeatio class are to be taken from the Channel Fleet, two from the Atlantic Fleet, and two of the Formidable classism the Mediterranean Fleet. The whole of the Royal Sovereign class is to be placed in the reserve without news. These are not old or Niele ships, for the oldest of them was built in 1892; and, of course, it is not intended to replace them by newer and better ships. The object of the Government is to save money, and enable Mr. Aeqnith to present a poplar Budget. But this reduction of ships is not the only one which the Navy will sustain. The crews who are now at sea in the ships to be discarded will live in barracks, and will lose some of their efficiency. Success in naval battles depends on the efficiency of the officers and men as on the quality of the ships in which they fight. Hitherto the public have had confidence in. the bluejackets, believing them to be as well trained as those of any Navy in existence. The scheme of the Government, if carried out, will destroy this confidence. In a naval war the battleships in the reserve might be commissioned to take the place of those sank or disabled, but sailors drawn from the reserve would not be as efficient as those who were constantly at sea, and they would be placed at a disadvantage in fighting German crews, who are believed to be as well trained aa our own are new. It was generally understood that both parties were agreed that it was absolutely necessary to maintain our naval supremacy, and also that they were agreed about the meaning of the term. It was an accepted doctrine that the British Navy most be able to meet the combined navies of the two strongest Powers, with a good chance of victory. Lord Charles Beresford said; "To make the British Fleet equal in fighting strength to its possible enemies—two other nations—it should be numerically superior at least by one third." When these sixteen battleships and four armoured risers are thrown away, it will be considerably inferior to the fleets of the two next strongest naval Powers. France and Germany will have 52 battleships against Great Britain's 39, or a superiority of 13. France and the United States will have a superiority of 6, and Germany and the United States a superiority of 2. It may be said that all these combinations are improbable. We are on good terms with both France aid United States, and neither of these Powers is likely to join Germany in attacking ns. It should be remembered, however, that changes in international polities occur with dramatic suddenness. We cannot afford to allow our existence as a nation to depend on the goodwill of other Powers.

div.head: The "African World"
div.p: SPECIAL EGYPTIAN SUPPLEMENT.

We must congratulate our London weekly contemporary "The African World" on the publication of their last supplement, which is devoted to Egypt, and which reflects infinite credit on editor, publisher, and printer. The comprehensiveness of its literary contents and the representativeness of its numerous and excellent illustrations make it a volume well worthy of addition to the libraries of all who are interested in' Egypt. The limited liability companies of Egypt are dealt with in a concise and simple manner, which cannot fail to be distortive to financier and layman alike, and several of Egypt's more important commercial interests are referred to in wider detail. Though the majority of articles are devoted to financial and commercial matters, ample space is given to subjects of less serious and important interest, prominent among which is an excellent description of street life in Cairo.

The illustrations, we have said, are both excellent and representative. Among the most instructive of these are a bird's-eye view oi the Nile valley and a commercial map, the former old which tells one at a glance the positions of the principal towns, villages, and monuments, while the latter gives one a very good idea of the products of the varions districts up to the borderland of the Congo States and British East Africa. The many photographs of the leading lights of Egypt— official, financial, and social—are exceptionally good.

div.head: The Bagdad Railway
div.p: FURTHER DIFFICULTIES ARISE.

Mezel Khan, sheikh of the Persian town and territory of Mchammerah, situated on the frontier of Persia and Asiatic Turkey and complying an important position at the confluence of the Karan and the Shatt-el-Arab, some 25 miles south-east of Basra, has been for some time in active correspondence with Mubarek-es-Saba, sheikh of the independent state of Koweit, in Turkish Arabia.

There are grounds (the Constantinople correspondent of the "Manchester Guardian" says) for attributing to Mezel Khan the design of severing all the ties that bind him to the Court of Teheran and - following the precedent set by Mubarek-es-Saba some years ago, when he broke with the Turks-of proclaiming Mobammerah an independent and autonomous State.

The defection of the Sheikh of Koweit deprived the Sultan of a valuable ally against the desert tribes, and the German promoters of the Bagdad line of the projected terminus at Koweit, which is the finest natural harbour on the Persian Gulf. It has always been understood that behind Sheikh Mubarak was to be found the British Government, and some support is given to this theory by Lord Cutzod's visit of a few years ago daring his Viceroyalty.

Mobammerah, as will be seen by the map, commands the left hank of the Shatt-el Arab, the great river formed by the iodination of the Tigris and Euphrates, and is strategically fitted to suspend all communication by water between Basra and Bagdad and the sea. Steamers of large burden now ply op the rivers as far as Bagdad.

div.head: Kelway's Manual.
div.p: The fifty-fifth edition of "Kelway's Mannal of Horticulture" (Kelway & Son, LaDgport) shows the progressive improvement of previous issues. It is a reliable and helpful handbook to the purchase and culture of the best plants and seeds for the garden and contains excellent illustrations of a very large number of species of plants. It is a "garden book" in the trine sense, and should be of great interest and vaine to all concerned in horticulture.

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
It is easily prepared and applied.
WHAT IT DOES
FRESKEL, covers well, and works easy Does not crack, peel, or show brush marks. Does not rub off.
ECONOMICAL - EFFECTIVE.
Shade Cards and Circulars on application to the manufacturers:
THOS. HINSHELWOOD & CO., LIMITED. ALEXANDRIA.
